div.p: Shift-based but you turn up at 8 o’clock in the morning sort of thing and if we were doing search warrants that day, for example, we would start
at 5am in the morning, we’d have a briefing, we’d go out, kick the doors in, arrest the individuals that we had to arrest and all the rest of it
and then you’re processing those people throughout the day. I never, ever finished on time, never finished on time I would ring my wife
“I’ll be late”, “I’ll be late”, “I’ll be late” and 8 hour days often turned into 12, 15, 20 hour days that was the nature of the beast with the job, and
the unit that we were on. The uniform shifts are different, they work 11 hour shifts but if you’re in an investigative role which we were
you can’t just go home and leave an individual in the cells to rot until the next day, there are rules and regulations and timeframes to adhere to
so you know going on from that if you weren’t out on an action day like that, sort of thing, you’re catching up with paperwork or putting
crime files together for court cases, chasing up forensic evidence or if you had a slack moment I just used to go out with a colleague
and we’d go out looking for drug dealers and stuff like that, you’ve just got to know where to look, they’re out there, target certain phone boxes
they always use the same ones because they’re not the brightest individuals and wait for the dealers to turn up and jump on them
and you’re just creating jobs from nothing, no intelligence just using a little bit of savvy really.
